Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Story: My phone buzzes in my pocket just as I pull up to the curb, where two travelers stand surrounded by suitcases. I see my mom’s name flash on the screen—she’s probably waiting for my daily update, wanting to know if I’ve eaten, how my day is going, if I’m safe. I know she expects a quick reply, maybe even a photo, and I can already imagine her worry growing with every minute I don’t respond. But the travelers are waving, already opening the trunk, and I know I need to help them load their bags, greet them with a smile, and make sure their ride is smooth and professional. They’re discussing how to split the fare, and I need to pay attention, answer their questions, and keep things moving. My phone vibrates again, more insistent this time. I feel the pressure mounting—my parents’ need for connection pulling me one way, my duty to my passengers pulling me another. I stand there, keys in hand, torn between the two worlds, my heart pounding as I try to decide which expectation to meet first.
